citation.article-title: Gordonia nitida sp. nov., a bacterium that degrades 3-ethylpyridine and 3-methylpyridine.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Gordonia nitida sp. nov.
Gordonia nitida (ni.ti'da. L. adj. nitida bright, shining, glossy, pertaining to the appearance of the colonies)
Cells are Gram-positive and non-motile.
Cells in the early growth phase are rods and cells in the exponential and stationary growth phases are cocci, which occur mainly in pairs or often singly and in short chains.
Colonies are orange-coloured, glossy and slightly convex with slightly irregular edges on TSA.
Neither substrate mycelia nor primary mycelia are found.
Grows well over a broad range of pH values (pH 6.0-9.0) but grow better in alkaline conditions (pH 8.0-9.0) ; growth is slow or inhibited at pH values below 5.0 and above 12.0.
Grows optimally at 30-37 °C; growth is very slow or inhibited at 7 °C and does not occur at 45 °C.
Catalase-, urease- and DNase-positive.
Oxidase-negative.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
Aesculin and Tween 80 are hydrolysed but arbutin, elastin, casein and starch are not hydrolysed.
D-Ribose, sucrose, glucose, D-turanose, D-trehalose, citrate, gluconate, L-alanine and L-proline are utilized.
D-galactose, D-arabitol, myo-inositol, L-rhamnose, L-aspartate, benzoate, succinate, L-leucine, L-valine and acetamide are not utilized.
Acids are produced from glucose, sucrose and D-trehalose.
Acids are not produced from D-galactose, L-rhamnose, myo-inositol or D-sorbitol.
Cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic acid, arabinose and galactose (wall chemotype IV).
The predominant menaquinone is MK-9(H2).
The major fatty acids are C16:0, C18:1ω9c and 10-methyl-C18:0 (TBSA).
Mycolic acids contain 47-55 carbon atoms.
The G+C content of the DNA is 67 mol% (as determined by HPLC).
Isolated from an industrial wastewater in Taegu, Korea.
The type strain is strain LE31T, which has been deposited in the Korean Collection for Type Cultures as KCTC 0605BPT and the Korean Culture Center of Microorganisms as KCCM 80004T.
